pull.title: tests: Use colors and dots in test_runner.py output only if standard output is a terminal
pull.body:
Use colors and dots in `test_runner.py` output only if standard output is a terminal -- allows for using the test runner output as input to other programs.

I found the need for this when parsing `test_runner.py` output while investigating intermittent functional test failures.

Before:

```
$ test/functional/test_runner.py wallet_hd.py > output 2>&1
$ less output
Temporary test directory at /tmp/test_runner_‚Çø_üèÉ_20190807_074115
ESC[1mWARNING!ESC[0m There is already a bitcoind process running on this system. Tests may fail unexpectedly due to resource contention!
Remaining jobs: [wallet_hd.py]
.......................................^M                                       ^M1/1 - ESC[1mwallet_hd.pyESC[0m passed, Duration: 20 s

ESC[1mTEST         | STATUS    | DURATION

ESC[0mESC[0;32mwallet_hd.py | ‚úì Passed  | 20 s
ESC[0mESC[1m
ALL          | ‚úì Passed  | 20 s (accumulated)
ESC[0mRuntime: 20 s
```

After:

```
$ test/functional/test_runner.py wallet_hd.py > output 2>&1
$ less output
Temporary test directory at /tmp/test_runner_‚Çø_üèÉ_20190807_074244
1/1 - wallet_hd.py passed, Duration: 20 s
WARNING! There is already a bitcoind process running on this system. Tests may fail unexpectedly due to resource contention!
Remaining jobs: [wallet_hd.py]

TEST         | STATUS    | DURATION

wallet_hd.py | ‚úì Passed  | 20 s

ALL          | ‚úì Passed  | 20 s (accumulated)
Runtime: 20 s
```

events.body: Could use `sys.stdout.isatty()` to automatically disable colors and progress dots?
@promag Good point -- I thought about that but I'm not sure `sys.stdout.isatty()` holds `True` in Travis where we want the dots at least. I'll investigate :-)

rename.to: tests: Use colors and dots in test_runner.py output only if standard output is a terminal

events.body: @promag Turns out `sys.stdout.isatty()` holds `True` also in Travis. Updated PR. Would you mind re-reviewing? :-)

events.message: tests: Use colors and dots in test_runner.py output only if standard output is a terminal -- allows for using the test runner output as input to other programs

events.body:
Looks good to me now,
ACK 37f2784952cb6f598f82922f9ce71d40c9d74e26

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -56,12 +56,13 @@
         stderr_mode = ctypes.c_int32()
         kernel32.GetConsoleMode(stderr, ctypes.byref(stderr_mode))
         kernel32.SetConsoleMode(stderr, stderr_mode.value | ENABLE_VIRTUAL_TERMINAL_PROCESSING)
-    # primitive formatting on supported
-    # terminal via ANSI escape sequences:
-    BOLD = ('\033[0m', '\033[1m')
-    GREEN = ('\033[0m', '\033[0;32m')
-    RED = ('\033[0m', '\033[0;31m')
-    GREY = ('\033[0m', '\033[1;30m')
+    if sys.stdout.isatty():
comments.body:
please call the `sys.stdout.isatty()` only once and assign it to a variable (`use_term_control` or something like that) if you use it later
I'd like to add an argument to override this, there are cases where one might want to redirect the output to something that doesn't identify as a tty but still supports terminal control sequences
(e.g. when calling the tests over SSH)
